title: wink
text: can install --date version package via github repo. example, ’ll use synthetic food dataset comes package. food dataset contains 2000 fictional survey responses, including demographics food attitude ratings.
code: pak::pak("jjmoncus/wink") library(wink) # In a real session, the data loads automatically when your package is attached. head(food, n = 5)

what: Percentages of var, split by by
title: wink
text: crosstab() function generates percentage table one variable (var) broken another () performs column--column statistical testing (represented letter rows). unweighted N’s, Design Effects (DEFF), Margins Sampling Error (MOSE), included bottom. crosstab likelihood pescetarian (pescetarian) taste meat (rating_meat).
code: crosstab(   data = food,   var = "pescetarian",   by = "rating_meat" )

title: wink
text: Example coming soon

title: wink
text: crosstab() automatically rounds whole percentages, can specify using digits.
code: crosstab(   data = food,   var = "pescetarian",   by = "rating_meat",   digits = 2 )

title: wink
text: can define NET (summary) categories using var_nets argument, takes named list character vectors. var_nets can also specified referring levels number. Notice NET rows inserted table, metadata rows (N, DEFF, MOSE) appended bottom.
code: crosstab(   data = food,   var = "veggie",   by = "rating_pizza",   var_nets = list(     "Low"  = c("Very Low", "Low"),     "High" = c("High", "Very High")     )   ) crosstab(   data = food,   var = "veggie",   by = "rating_pizza",   var_nets = list(     "Low"  = c(1:2),     "High" = c(4:5)     ) )

title: wink
text: column letters reflect columns table eventually fit exported excel. default, first column presumed fall column C, dictated default parameter st_col_start = 3. can theory set new default specifying st_col_start, just wanted export single crosstab.

title: wink
text: banner() generates multiple crosstab() tables common target variable (var) combines one wide table. Columns grouped variable. weight, digits, var_nets work crosstab()
code: banner(   data = food,   var = "vegan",   bys = c("rating_meat", "rating_pizza", "rating_sushi", "rating_veg") ) banner(   data = food,   var = "vegan",   bys = c("rating_meat", "rating_pizza", "rating_sushi", "rating_veg"),   weight = NULL, # example coming soon   digits = 2,   var_nets = list(Low = 1:2, High = 4:5) )

title: wink
text: write_banners() function takes list banners banner() exports single, formatted Excel file. separates banner groups borders creates hyperlinked Table Contents. typical workflow write list banners using purrr::map()
code: banners <- c("pescetarian", "veggie", "vegan") %>%   purrr::set_names() %>% # name the vector after itself, not required but convenient   purrr::map(function(x) {          banner(       data = food,        var = x,       bys = paste0("rating_", c("meat", "pizza", "sushi", "veg")))   })       write_banners(   banners_list = banners,   file = "my_survey_results.xlsx",   overwrite = TRUE )

title: Authors and Citation
text: J.J. Moncus. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Moncus J (2025). wink: Crosstab Signifiance Testing Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case). R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://jjmoncus.github.io/wink/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {wink: Crosstab and Signifiance Testing for Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case)},   author = {J.J. Moncus},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://jjmoncus.github.io/wink/}, }

what: Crosstab and Signifiance Testing for Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case)
title: Crosstab and Signifiance Testing for Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case)
text: goal wink provide foundational functionality generating tables survey estimates, including significance testing.

title: Crosstab and Signifiance Testing for Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case)
text: can install development version wink GitHub rep :
code: devtools::install_github("jjmoncus/wink",                           build_vignettes = TRUE, # helpful to see vignettes, set to FALSE if needed                          force = TRUE  # helpful if you've installed previous versions, forces an override, set to FALSE if needed                          )

title: Crosstab and Signifiance Testing for Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case)
text: See vignette("wink") intro package, visit Get Started link website. questions, reach J.J. Moncus jjmoncus706@gmail.com, raise issue.

what: Create Banner Crosstabs with Statistical Testing — banner
title: Create Banner Crosstabs with Statistical Testing — banner
text: function generates multiple crosstabs using banner variables target variable, applying statistical testing across columns. combines results single table appropriate column dividers presentation.

title: Create Banner Crosstabs with Statistical Testing — banner
code: banner(   data,   var,   bys,   weight = NULL,   var_nets = NULL,   digits = 0,   min_group_n = 100 )

title: Create Banner Crosstabs with Statistical Testing — banner
text: data survey data us var character string specifying target variable name analyzed banner variables bys vector character strings, element represents banner variable name cross-tabulated target variable min_group_n integer specifying minimum sample size threshold statistical testing. Cells fewer observations may included testing. Default 100. design survey design object (typically survey package) containing survey data design specifications, like weighted percentages. Defaults NULL

title: Create Banner Crosstabs with Statistical Testing — banner
text: data frame containing combined crosstab results following attributes: col_dividers: numeric vector indicating column divisions occur var: target variable name used analysis bys: list banner variables used analysis

title: Create Banner Crosstabs with Statistical Testing — banner
text: function processes banner variable sequentially, creating crosstabs via crosstab() statistical testing. Statistical testing starts column B progresses subsequent columns based number columns table. Column dividers tracked stored attributes facilitate proper formatting presentation combined results.

title: Create Banner Crosstabs with Statistical Testing — banner
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create a survey design object library(survey) design <- svydesign(ids = ~1, data = my_data, weights = ~weight)  # Define banner variables my_bys <- list("age_group", "gender", "region")  # Generate banner crosstabs result <- banners(   design = design,   var = "satisfaction",   bys = my_bys,   min_group_n = 50 )  # Access column dividers attr(result, "col_dividers") } # }

title: Rewriting the crosstab function — crosstab
text: Rewriting crosstab function

title: Rewriting the crosstab function — crosstab
code: crosstab(   data,   var,   by,   weight = NULL,   var_nets = NULL,   digits = 0,   min_group_n = 100,   st_col_start = 3 )

what: Building a crosstab from its inputs — crosstab_builder
title: Building a crosstab from its inputs — crosstab_builder
text: Building crosstab inputs

title: Building a crosstab from its inputs — crosstab_builder
code: crosstab_builder(   baby_crosstab,   sig_test_table,   n_unweighted_row,   deff_row,   mose_row )

what: safely coerce something to a double, or not — double_or_not
title: safely coerce something to a double, or not — double_or_not
text: Might use write values excel sheets numbers instead text, necessary

title: safely coerce something to a double, or not — double_or_not
code: double_or_not(x)

what: Synthetic Survey Data on Food Attitudes and Eating Styles — food
title: Synthetic Survey Data on Food Attitudes and Eating Styles — food
text: synthetic dataset containing responses 2,000 fictional U.S. adult survey respondents regarding ratings various food types self-reported likelihood adopting different eating styles (Pescetarian, Vegetarian, Vegan) next 12 months. dataset intended use package examples, tutorials, unit testing.

title: Synthetic Survey Data on Food Attitudes and Eating Styles — food
code: food

title: Synthetic Survey Data on Food Attitudes and Eating Styles — food
text: tibble 2,000 rows 10 variables: unique_id (Integer, Label: "Unique ID") unique identifier respondent. age (Integer, Label: "S1. old ?") Respondent's age, ranging 18 80. gender (Factor, Label: "S2. following best describes ?") Self-reported gender identity. region (Factor, Label: "S3. region U.S. ?") U.S. region residence, including categories like "West Coast" "Mountain West". rating_meat (Ordered Factor, Label: "Q1a...:Meat") Rating much respondent likes meat. rating_pizza (Ordered Factor, Label: "Q1b...:Pizza") Rating much respondent likes pizza. rating_sushi (Ordered Factor, Label: "Q1c...:Sushi") Rating much respondent likes sushi. rating_veg (Ordered Factor, Label: "Q1d...:Vegetables") Rating much respondent likes vegetables. pescetarian (Ordered Factor, Label: "Q2. likely eat pescetarian...") Self-reported likelihood choosing pescetarian diet. veggie (Ordered Factor, Label: "Q3. likely eat vegetarian...") Self-reported likelihood choosing vegetarian diet. vegan (Ordered Factor, Label: "Q4. likely eat vegan...") Self-reported likelihood choosing vegan diet.

title: Synthetic Survey Data on Food Attitudes and Eating Styles — food
text: synthetically generated dataset created demonstration testing purposes.

title: Synthetic Survey Data on Food Attitudes and Eating Styles — food
text: rating scales used food items (Q1a-Q1d) 5-point Likert scales following levels: much dislike Somewhat dislike equally like dislike Somewhat like much like likelihood scales used eating styles (Q2-Q4) 5-point scales following levels: Low Low Moderate High High

what: hardcoded test for significant differences between two percentages — hardcode_sig_test
title: hardcoded test for significant differences between two percentages — hardcode_sig_test
text: hardcoded test significant differences two percentages

title: hardcoded test for significant differences between two percentages — hardcode_sig_test
code: hardcode_sig_test(p1, n1, deff1, p2, n2, deff2)

what: Switch between numbers and Excel lettered columns — num_to_excel_col
title: Switch between numbers and Excel lettered columns — num_to_excel_col
text: Switch numbers Excel lettered columns

title: Switch between numbers and Excel lettered columns — num_to_excel_col
code: num_to_excel_col(x)

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
code: lhs %>% rhs

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling rhs(lhs).

what: Do significance testing on a crosstab — sig_test_table
title: Do significance testing on a crosstab — sig_test_table
text: Isolating functionality related significance testing, easier maintenance

title: Do significance testing on a crosstab — sig_test_table
code: sig_test_table(baby_crosstab, n_unweighteds, deffs, col_start = 3)

what: wink: Crosstab and Signifiance Testing for Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case) — wink-package
title: wink: Crosstab and Signifiance Testing for Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case) — wink-package
text: Quick easy crosstabs banners, displaying weighted (unweighted) survey estimates exported Excel.

title: wink: Crosstab and Signifiance Testing for Weighted Survey Estimates (Title Case) — wink-package
text: Maintainer: J.J. Moncus jjmoncus706@gmail.com

what: Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook — write_banners
title: Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook — write_banners
text: function takes list banner crosstab tables exports formatted Excel workbook. table becomes separate worksheet appropriate styling, including borders column dividers. Table Contents sheet hyperlinks automatically generated.

title: Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook — write_banners
code: write_banners(banners_list, file, overwrite = TRUE)

title: Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook — write_banners
text: banners_list list data frames, typically output banner analysis functions. element following attributes: target: Character string used worksheet name col_dividers: Numeric vector indicating column positions right borders label: Optional character string display labels (falls back target name) file character string specifying output file path Excel workbook. include .xlsx extension. overwrite logical value indicating whether overwrite existing file. Default TRUE.

title: Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook — write_banners
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side effect creating writing Excel file.

title: Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook — write_banners
text: function creates formatted Excel workbook following features: worksheets: element input list becomes separate sheet formatting: Applies medium borders column dividers headers Table Contents: dedicated first sheet hyperlinks sheets Styled borders: Right borders column divider positions bottom borders headers Automatic naming: Uses target attribute sheet names Table Contents sheet automatically positioned first sheet includes: formatted header larger, bold text Hyperlinked entries worksheet (note: hyperlink functionality may limitations) Wider column width better readability Blue tab color visual distinction Column dividers applied based col_dividers attribute, contain column numbers right borders applied visually separate different banner sections.

title: Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook — write_banners
text: hyperlink functionality Table Contents may limitations depending Excel version settings (noted function comments). data frame input list must required attributes (target col_dividers) proper formatting. Missing attributes may result errors suboptimal formatting.

title: Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook — write_banners
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Assuming you have banner analysis results banner_results <- banners(   design = my_design,   target = "satisfaction",   banners = list("age_group", "gender", "region") )  # Export to Excel with default settings write_banners(   banners_list = list(satisfaction = banner_results),   file = "survey_banners.xlsx" )  # Export multiple banner analyses multiple_results <- list(   satisfaction = banner_results,   awareness = other_banner_results )  write_banners(   banners_list = multiple_results,   file = "all_survey_results.xlsx",   overwrite = FALSE ) } # }
